On August 31, 2020, the first day of school, students have a half-day of school.

High school students will attend in the morning from 9:00 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. with 1st, 2nd, and 3rd class periods. Middle school school students will attend 1st, 2nd, and 3rd period classes from 9:00 a.m. to 11:50 a.m. Elementary students will attend their morning synchronous “live” classes ending by 12:15 p.m. Students do not attend the small group sessions in the afternoon.

Students in Options #2a and 2b will be contacted by their teachers to meet the morning of August 31.

Students will attend remote/virtual full days of school starting on Tuesday, September 1.

What are you reading this summer? El Sol Elementary teacher Becky Cuppernull recommends, "I Am Gandhi" by Brad Meltzer. "This thoughtful and entertaining book tells the true story of civil-rights hero Gandhi’s life through beautiful illustrations. A diverse group of 25 artists donated their works in order to raise money for an organization that embodies Gandhi’s mission to promote peace. I love this book because it shows that the first step in fighting injustice is standing up for what you believe is right, a lesson all children should learn. While this book would be most suitable for kids ages 8 and up, I would recommend it to anyone interested in learning about the life of Gandhi and his peaceful fight for civil rights."

Watch this very special program at noon on Friday at BLACKFREEDOM.org or on Facebook Live

This timely event features cultural performances from Africa and across America, educational content and appearances by:

Lonnie G. Bunch III, the first African American and first historian to serve as the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution
Dr. Johnnetta Betsch Cole, anthropologist, educator, museum director and the first female African American president of Spelman College
The Honorable Carla Hayden, Librarian of Congress, the first woman and the first African American to lead the national library

The Michigan Education Association and other state education organizations are hosting “Our Children, Our Future,” a virtual rally on Facebook Live at 5 p.m., Friday, May 29.

U.S. Sen. Gary Peters, State Rep. Sheryl Kennedy, and other special guests are expected to attend the event, which is being organized by the MEA, AFT Michigan, Middle Cities Education Association, Michigan Association of Superintendents and Administrators, Michigan Association of School Boards, Michigan Association of Secondary School Principals, and Michigan Association of Administrators of Special Education.

“Michigan's students and schools need help from the federal government during this pandemic,” the MEA said in a prepared statement. “Faced with even greater needs than before, our schools may see funding cut because of the economic downturn caused by COVID-19. We need to speak up and get federal funding to continue providing a great public education for every student.”

Participants can join the event by signing up at https://www.mobilize.us/mea/event/276399/.

Thursday evening, Kalamazoo Public Schools (KPS) announced that KPS high schools would hold virtual graduations in June in lieu of live, in-person ceremonies. KPS opted to hold virtual graduations based on the COVID-19 pandemic, the current restrictions on the assembly of large audiences in the state of Michigan, and not knowing when these restrictions might be lifted.

There have been numerous requests to hold in-person graduation ceremonies since Thursday’s announcement. In response to these requests, KPS today announced tentative plans to hold in-person commencement ceremonies in August. The dates for the following schools would be:

Tuesday, Aug. 4: Phoenix High School
Wednesday, Aug. 5: Loy Norrix High School
Thursday, Aug. 6: Kalamazoo Central High School

The ability to hold graduation ceremonies in August will be dependent on Gov. Gretchen Whitmer’s orders and safety guidelines. Details regarding the time, location, and any restrictions on the number of guests allowed to attend will be announced at a later date.

The Kalamazoo Public Schools Board of Education has announced the cancellation of the scheduled regular meeting on April 16, 2020. Board President Patti Sholler-Barber stated, “There is not an urgent need to hold a meeting and distract the administration from their work on the Continuity of Learning Plan. The education of our students comes first.”

Interim Superintendent Gary Start stated, “When the meeting is rescheduled, we will work with the Board of Education to ensure a secure, well-run meeting. The cancellation of the April 16 meeting does not cause any disruption in the work we are doing and follows suit with what many other school districts and governmental bodies are doing.”

Kalamazoo Nature Center
March 12 at 4:00 PM ·

KNC is doing its part to FLATTEN THE CURVE

As of March 13th, KNC will be exercising an abundance of caution to keep our visitors, volunteers, and staff safe.
The KNC Visitor Center will be CLOSED and all public programs and will be canceled effective March 13th through April 12.
School programs will be adjusted on a case-by-case basis. Nature’s Way Preschool and Heronwood Field Station will follow the Kalamazoo Public Schools schedule.

As of March 19th, KNC is extending the closure of all programs and events for three more weeks, through April 12.

Watch for weekly program updates here and at NatureCenter.org.

KNC TRAILS will remain OPEN and FREE of charge each day from 9am-7:30pm. Outdoor time is one of the best things to do for well-being during times such as this.
Portable restrooms will be available.

KNC has a no dogs on trail policy. There is free parking just inside the main KNC entrance for dog walkers to park and use the Kalamazoo River Valley Trail.

The KPS Class of 2009 is invited to participate in the Kalamazoo Promise 10-Year Survey!

The Kalamazoo Promise
November 27, 2019 at 1:48 PM ·

The KPS Class of 2009 is invited to participate in the Kalamazoo Promise 10-Year Survey!

This survey is intended for alumni of Kalamazoo Public Schools 10 years after their high school graduation, and is designed to shed light on how the Kalamazoo Promise helps support further education and workforce preparation, as well as the ways in which the Promise could be improved to support these goals for all KPS students.

You do not need to have received Promise funding, or even have been eligible to receive funding, to fill out the survey. You just need to be a KPS high school graduate from the class of 2009.

To thank you for your time, all eligible individuals who complete the survey will receive a $25 electronic Amazon gift card. In addition to that, those who complete the survey before December 20th will be entered into a drawing to win a $250 and $100 Amazon gift card.

Please click the following link to take the survey: http://bit.ly/10YearSurveyCO2009
